channel.title: Replacing Backslashes [Java]
channel.description:
I'm trying to replace all backslashes, but it doesn't work. How can I turn off regular expressions when using the replace() method?
[code=Java] chat = chat.replace("\\", ""); [/code]

item.title: Replacing Backslashes [Java]
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:25, topic:443083”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=545772.msg4002847#msg4002847 date=1338252036]
Did you read my post? I was talking about making sure his code would compile if he used ’ around \ to make sure it was being recognized as the correct character, not using it as the solution. Whether he did replace(’\’, ‘a’), replace(’\’, ‘*’), replace(’\’, ‘7’) would have made no difference. It was just a potential debugging practice. OP has solved the issue anyway and said it was something completely different either way
[/quote]

Good job on finding an excuse and exiting the debate gracefully, even though you lost. Nice tactics, Davidi2.[/quote]i don’t consider parroting the deduced a viable debate tactic either, so perhaps you could shut up too.

Read full topic

Debate? wut. I said my piece before you even posted…

item.title: Replacing Backslashes [Java]
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:22, topic:443083”][quote author=The Enforcer link=topic=545772.msg4002674#msg4002674 date=1338234078]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=545772.msg4002669#msg4002669 date=1338233489]

… (replace uses just char, if it doesn’t work it’s because some weird object casting), except maybe try using ’ instead of " to make sure java is recognizing \ as a legal char (well, an escape character and a char) …

String.replace() has two overloaded declarations:
[ig]http://puu.sh/xlga[/img]
Note that String implements CharSequence.
[/quote]I know it has both methods, I was pointing out that he could make sure his escaped backslash was being recognized correctly by using ’ instead of ", because you’d get a compilation error if you use a non-character inside single quotes

You can’t represent the absence of characters with a character literal, silly boy.
[/quote]What are you talking about?[/quote]

Talking about the initial help request.

[quote=“whackatre, post:1, topic:443083”] chat = chat.replace("\\", ""); [/quote]

Do you realize that you can’t represent an empty string as a character literal? The char version of replace() couldn’t possibly be suitable in this case.

Read full topic

item.title: Replacing Backslashes [Java]
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:21, topic:443083”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=545772.msg4002669#msg4002669 date=1338233489]

… (replace uses just char, if it doesn’t work it’s because some weird object casting), except maybe try using ’ instead of " to make sure java is recognizing \ as a legal char (well, an escape character and a char) …

String.replace() has two overloaded declarations:
[ig]http://puu.sh/xlga[/img]
Note that String implements CharSequence.
[/quote]I know it has both methods, I was pointing out that he could make sure his escaped backslash was being recognized correctly by using ’ instead of ", because you’d get a compilation error if you use a non-character inside single quotes

You can’t represent the absence of characters with a character literal, silly boy.[/quote]What are you talking about?

Read full topic

item.title: Replacing Backslashes [Java]
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:20, topic:443083”][quote author=veer link=topic=545772.msg4002660#msg4002660 date=1338232944]

… (replace uses just char, if it doesn’t work it’s because some weird object casting), except maybe try using ’ instead of " to make sure java is recognizing \ as a legal char (well, an escape character and a char) …

String.replace() has two overloaded declarations:

Note that String implements CharSequence.
[/quote]I know it has both methods, I was pointing out that he could make sure his escaped backslash was being recognized correctly by using ’ instead of ", because you’d get a compilation error if you use a non-character inside single quotes[/quote]

You can’t represent the absence of characters with a character literal, silly boy.

Read full topic

item.title: Replacing Backslashes [Java]
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“veer, post:18, topic:443083”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=545772.msg4002341#msg4002341 date=1338191545]
… (replace uses just char, if it doesn’t work it’s because some weird object casting), except maybe try using ’ instead of " to make sure java is recognizing \ as a legal char (well, an escape character and a char) …
[/quote]
String.replace() has two overloaded declarations:

Note that String implements CharSequence.[/quote]I know it has both methods, I was pointing out that he could make sure his escaped backslash was being recognized correctly by using ’ instead of ", because you’d get a compilation error if you use a non-character inside single quotes

Read full topic

item.title: Replacing Backslashes [Java]
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“veer, post:18, topic:443083”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=545772.msg4002341#msg4002341 date=1338191545]
… (replace uses just char, if it doesn’t work it’s because some weird object casting), except maybe try using ’ instead of " to make sure java is recognizing \ as a legal char (well, an escape character and a char) …
[/quote]
String.replace() has two overloaded declarations:

Note that String implements CharSequence.[/quote]
excellent point, single character replacement should be done using chars - str.replace(’\’, ’ ')

Read full topic

… (replace uses just char, if it doesn’t work it’s because some weird object casting), except maybe try using ’ instead of " to make sure java is recognizing \ as a legal char (well, an escape character and a char) …

String.replace() has two overloaded declarations:

Note that String implements CharSequence.

item.title: Replacing Backslashes [Java]
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

You’re correct, my mistake. I always just found it weird that they had replaceAll(regex) and replace(charseq) that do the same thing, so the method names throw me off. I still think the issue may be that he wants to replace / not , but he has yet to reply as to his intentions…

Read full topic

item.title: Replacing Backslashes [Java]
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

Davidi2:

You probably do want to use replaceAll like Taharok suggested though, unless you’re only trying to remove a leading /, in which case the substring method would be easier.

replace() doesn’t just replace the first occurrence if that’s what you’re trying to say. It’s the same as replaceAll() except it doesn’t use regex. Seeing as whackatre doesn’t want to use regex, replace() is what he wants, but I have no idea why it isn’t working for him.

Read full topic

item.title: Replacing Backslashes [Java]
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Are you sure you even want to replace ? I see you are talking about chat, and in chat most people use / for clan chat and such. Your original code is correct (replace uses just char, if it doesn’t work it’s because some weird object casting), except maybe try using ’ instead of " to make sure java is recognizing \ as a legal char (well, an escape character and a char).

You probably do want to use replaceAll like Taharok suggested though, unless you’re only trying to remove a leading /, in which case the substring method would be easier.

Read full topic

item.title: Replacing Backslashes [Java]
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:9, topic:443083”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=545772.msg4001416#msg4001416 date=1338063114]
Uh, replaceAll should work.
[/quote]

Still uses regex ^^[/quote]

Wrong, only uses regex. replace() just uses regular sequences. Regex is what you want to use here, so I really don’t understand why you are complaining. \ is a valid regex pattern.

Read full topic
